Award.AwardTitle: PKAL Capital Region Network Workshop at the University of the District of Columbia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Capital Regional Network Workshop at the University of the District of Columbia (UCD) aims to bring together UDC and its partners, Morgan State University, Hampton University, and Bowie State University, with Project Kaleidoscope of the Association of American Colleges and Universities to enhance professional development opportunities for science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) faculty and expand the national discourse on broadening participation in undergraduate STEM education by involving Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). This workshop presents an opportunity to capture the best practices of HBCUs, which are known to result in positive outcomes for African American STEM students, and transfer them to a broader range of institution types. Two-hundred faculty and administrators are expected to attend the workshop.

This initiative will help STEM faculty and institutions in the Capital Regional Network to build their knowledge of how students learn; develop their capacity for and use of best practices in STEM pedagogy; facilitate their use of effective inside- and outside-the-classroom STEM learning experiences; help to integrate research into the undergraduate courses and curriculum; and promote collaboration among faculty across the institutions in improving learning outcomes in STEM for majors and non-majors alike. It is expected that this regional network will sustain itself and will grow because of the infusion of a broader audience of STEM faculty and its track record in enhancing STEM faculty self-efficacy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of the District of Columbia (UDC) successfully initiated the Project Kaleidoscope Capital (PKAL) Capital Region Network by conducting four annual network events during the project period. The inaugural conference was at UDC. Each event was hosted by a Historically Black College/University (HBCU) in the Washington, D.C. metropolitan region, and involved up to 100 participants from 32 institutions. The convenings were one-day, highly interactive professional development workshops for faculty in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). The project team received positive feedback for each workshop and is currently planning for a fifth session. 

This project brought together HBCUs with the Association of American Colleges and Universities’ Project Kaleidoscope to enhance STEM faculty professional development opportunities and broaden participation. The workshops provided a platform for HBCU faculty to share their effective broadening participation strategies with other institutions and increase their confidence in implementing impactful active learning approaches. Through the keynote speeches and the concurrent sessions, the pedagogies and best practices were disseminated to the participants that came from various institutions in the Capital Region. The project facilitated a complete paradigm shift in undergraduate STEM teaching by meeting the need for 1) different approaches at both the individual and institutional levels, and 2) a targeted focus on broadening the participation of women as well as both men and women of color.
